div1.p: Kean promises that he will assist Hench in his research. He suggests that Hench contact Truby for more information.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Albert E. Truby, August 8, 1940

opener.dateline:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON, D. C.
Wed. Aug.8-
1940

div1.p:
Your very interesting letter about
Dr. Hench Lazear came on the 5th &
I gave it to Ireland next day- He
brought it back next day & said he
saw no reason why you should with-
hold anything in it from Dr. Hench.
It is also my opinion, and my comments
are of no great importance- Here they are.
In 1st line 2nd paragraph you have Gen. Lee's
Hdqrs Dept of Pinar del Rio which of course
should be Havana and Pinar del Rio,
Camp Columbia being in Havana Province-
In the next line Gen Fitzhugh Lee's name
is spelled Fitzhue which was of course
the stenog's slip-

In 1st line bottom par- 1st page October 1, 1900
should be Oct. 4 1900. I get from my diary
that on Oct. 3rd I was in Matanzas on an
inspection trip & in the evening went on
board the transport Crook, which was in
harbor, to see Reed & talked with him about
Lazear's death- He landed in Havana the
next morning as no ship could pass the
Morro until sunrise- My diary notes a long
talk with Reed on 6th in which he told me
the story of Lazear being bitten by a wild
mosquito at Las Animas and I have
always accepted that account until I
talked with you here in Washington
since my retirement- It was I who
told Dr. Hench that he should get in
communication with you- You saw much
more than I did of Reed at that time
3
since I was much occupied with my
duties at Hdqrs 16 orphan asylurus etc-
As regards Lazear he came to Cuba be-
four Reed but because he had been
recommended by Prof. Welch to Reed
for the yellow fever work- This was
the way I understood it- The Board
was created by S. O. 122 A. Y.O. Par. 34 - May 24,
1900 but as Lazear came to Cuba in Feb 1900
the board must have new planned or in contem-
plation some months before its creation for
this to have been the case- It may be of
course that Prof. Welch's recommendation may
have been given after Lazear had come to
Cuba- Dr. Hench spent most of the day
June 17 with me- I was much impressed
with his zeal and earnestness- No amount
of trouble is too great to get the bottom facts
2
5
Did he write you that he found the Cubans
had bought the piece of land below the rail-
road to Playa where our little yellow fever hospital
was located, and had put up a sign there
under the impression that it was the location
of Camp Lazear! He finally got hold of the
sister of the man who owned the land where
Camp Lazear really was & took her out
there & had her identify the real place.
Her brother had died some time ago-
Moran helped too in this identification-
He took photographs of everything- I think
we should help him all we can-

I am delighted that you are going to
print your recollection of this famous
episode- Gen. Ireland asked what
were the statements of Agramonte's that
you reproaced us for indorsing and
I could not remember what you were
5
* see P.55
referring to. His statement about the
putting of the infected mosquito on
X. Y. (Wth H. Dean, 7th Cav.) always seemed
to me to have been rather unlikely,
but I had no facts at my command
to disprove it and so never said any-
thing about it- One's memory plays
queer tricks with even the best of men
at times - Dr. Pinto who I have always
regarded as a five fellow made some
surprising statements about his con-
nection with the Reed Board but I
did not see any use in disputing
them and have no doubt he was
perfectly sincere & honest in his
belief as to his accuracy- Well I must
stop- Be sure to finish your memoir
and to let me have a copy before
C2
B5
6
I shuffle off- I was 80 in June
and am getting quite infirm-
cracking up is Ireland's favorite
expression- He dont use it about
me now because it is too obviously
true- He is the dearest friend in
the world and spends his time
helping his friends-

This account. of X. Y. was not
that in his sworn statement
but in an article-

P. S. Before closing my letter I read
over your pen-letter again and real-
ized that Senate Doc. 822 was my compila-
tion published by Senator Owen which
I keep always at hand bound in
half morocco and never lend to anyone-
So I have turned to page 25 and read
Agramonte's statement of what he did.
It seems now that it was not true that
“the best in friendship existed between all
the members of the board” but I did not
7-
know as much then as I do not
especially about Carroll- It
was Carroll that told me that
Agramonte was immune and so
did not deserve the same credit
as the other members of the board.
Agramonte afterwards told me that
he left Cuba as a small child
and he did not know whether
he was immune or not-

Dr. Roger Post Ames claimed to be
an immune & was appointed
by Reed to look after the experi-
mental cases on that account-
Did you know that later he took
to his bed in the Columbia Hospital
diagnosed his own case as yellow
fever at least I suppose he did - and
was discharged after 4 or 5 days with
C2
B5
8
a diagnosis of yellow fever!
And now for some years his widow
who is good looking and a Texas poli-
tician, very near to Senator Shepherd
Chairman of the Senate Military Com-
mittee - has been trying to get his
name added to the Yellow Fever
Roll of Honor, so that she can have
the pension of $100. a month and
her boys have the gold medal-

I think her claim has passed the
Senate she has at any rate a favor-
able Report from the committee-
Did you know that Dr. Ames did some
experimenting on his own hook at Fort
McIntosh Texas in 1903- He infected some mosqui-
toes & put them on a young soldier David
D. Driscoll Co. F. 26. Inf. who had a very
severe case & had to be discharged-

2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON, D. C.

So Driscoll applied to be put on
the Y. F. Roll of Honor-

Well I must stop gossiping-
Poor Col. Ashburn is slowly dying
of a very painful cancer of the
bladder- I have just been talking to
Mrs Ashburn over the phone-

Love to that dear lady Mrs. T.
in which Mrs K wishes to join me
div1.closer:
Your friend always J. R. Kean Write me what were the misstatements
that you had in mind in Agramonte's
statement- I dont see anything so very
bad-
